reviewText:
I know Canabalt was instrumental in kickstarting the infinite runner genre, and I know I'm going to get a lot of hate for this, but I honestly can't recommend this PC port. It's not about the gameplay; the gameplay is fine, and always has been. But I found this port to be rife with technical issues.

This game is buggy. My god, this game is buggy.

You probably already know what Canabalt is, but if not, it's a very simplistic game where you play as a man running and jumping across rooftops, and the goal is to earn a high score by running as far as possible before inevitably making a mistake and dying. There's only one button used to jump, but you'll have to learn to aim and adjust that jump to hairpin perfection if you want to survive for long. You speed up the longer you run, and you can trip over boxes to slow down. Problem is, if you are running too slow, you won't be able to jump on rising I-beams in time or run across falling buildings, but if you're running too fast, you won't have time to adjust your jump to land on tiny platforms. So it's all about running into boxes when you need to, and maintaining a perfect pace, hoping the game doesn't throw anything too tricky at you. It's a good balance between skill and luck. Otherwise, that's pretty much it; if you're expecting a game with tons of content, this isn't it. But as far as low-investment casual games go, Canabalt is one of the most tried and true.

The graphics are stylish and gritty, and the whole immersive atmosphere of an alien invasion is probably the best part of the game. The Danny Baranowsky track RUN!" is awesome and never seems to get old.

The new PC port adds some slightly better graphics
date: and extra features that weren't in the original mobile version. There's a new 2-player mode where you try to run alongside a friend
recommended: and your scores are added together for your final total. It's fun for a little while
hoursPlayed: and if your friend abandons you
voteText: it's easy enough to play as two players yourself; it's just one extra button
helpfulPercent: after all. There are also some new challenge modes
votesHelpful: most of which are the same game but with some tweaks
votesTotal: like replacing all the random obstacles with one kind of obstacle. And of course
votesFunny: now we have Steamworks features like cloud synch
column18: it's much harder on a keyboard than it is on a touch screen to make the tiny tap-jumps which the game will sometimes require for your survival
column19: unless you have very thin keys. Luckily
column20: you can also use the mouse.\n\nSo what are my complaints? Well
column21: here are just a few of the issues I ran into:\n\n* The game is not alt+tab friendly at all. After returning from an alt+tab
column22: I've had a wide number of glitches ranging from infinitely looping menus
column24: to soft-locked death screens.\n\n* The game seems to hang a lot in the middle of the run
column25: notably when kicking boxes. I assume this is due to the game buffering the different box kicking sound effects the first time they are played
column26: but it has ruined many runs for me
column27: especially during co-op.\n\n* After some extended co-op sessions with two actual people
column28: we have concluded that there is a bug which periodically causes one player's controls to make the other player jump
column29: even if they're already in midair
column30: causing an awkward and impossible midair jump. It's not something I noticed when controlling two players myself
column31: but it became very apparent with an actual second player.\n\n* Sometimes when you kick a box
column32: another box somewhere else on the screen will mysteriously get kicked also. This is very apparent while running at high speeds on the "box tripper" challenge. This
column33: combined with the "wrong player control" issue described above
column34: indicates that there's some kind of pointer / memory corruption happening.\n\n* On more than one occasion
column35: I've restarted a run and all the buildings were gone
column36: and I kept instantly falling to my death. When I tried to quit
column37: the game soft-locked with a white screen.\n\n* The Game Over menu is very lazily implemented. You can't merely press a button to restart the run
column38: but you have to use the arrow keys or the mouse to select the "restart" option. The default option on the Game Over menu depends on where your mouse cursor is at the time you died; so if you make sure your mouse cursor is at the bottom-right corner of the screen while playing
column39: then you can hit "enter" to restart the run when you die. Otherwise you might open the options or something.\n\n* Kicking a box immediately after coming out of a roll from a high jump will sometimes cause the character's running animation to freeze
column40: making him look like he's skating across the rooftops.\n\n* Very wonky physics at high speeds; on at least two occasions I've jumped straight through solid objects at breakneck speeds
column41: like when playing the "Panic" challenge.\n\n* The jump button is the only button you can remap
column42: despite the game menus using several other keys.\n\nOverall
column43: I just don't understand why something so simple as Canabalt can be screwed up and left without so much polish for a proper PC release. I mean
column44: this is not a complex game; would it really have been that hard not to leave in so many bugs?\n\nIf you just want an occasional run across the rooftops in single player on your PC instead of your phone
column45: this port seems to hold up in that regard -- although you can also just Google "Canabalt" and play a web version of it completely for free. I am just disappointed that what was supposed to be a definitive version of a great game is
column47: just a lazy mobile port.\n\nAchievement hunters: this is not an easy 100%. Not that there's anything wrong with that from a game design perspective (though some might raise objections that the game expects you to survive for 40
column48: 000 meters with so many random luck elements involved)
column49: but just don't expect to get the last few achievements unless you're very persistent and dedicated."

reviewText:
Canabalt is a remaster of sorts for the flash game canabalt if you wanne check out the flash version  click here [www.kongregate.com]


Gameplay Canabalt is a score attack platformer.
You control the game with 1 button.
You gain speed over time, you jump over buildings and get over the obstacles( boxes windows crumbling building’s bomb’s)
The more speed you get the further you jump.
The boxes can be really helpfull to get rid of speed so you dont go to far.
Then you have the different platforms like billboards and construction cranes.
And you have windows which are the most difficuilt of em all, since if you go to high you drop down you go to low you drop down so you have to be really precise.
Then you have the challenges which are the new additions to this version, you have 8 of them some are pretty easy like the invisible buildings one.
You have 2 goals for challenges for like howfar you need to go.
Its a pretty simple game and can be really addicting or good for ill play 1 round and then do a other thing.

Graphics and audioThe game has a nice black and white artstyle.
You have a 3d mode which makes everything look 3d i personally didnt like it, it made me play badly.
In the background you see a city being destroyed and ships flying over.
You have a female and male character which is a nice detail.
The soundtrack only has two tracks but is catchy and made by danny B.

Story The city is being destroyed and you run.

Final verdictThe game is a solid one click score attack platformer with some new content which wasnt in the flash version.
there are plenty of obstacles like bombs crumbling buildings etc and everything is procedural generated.
If you’re looking for a simple but challenging score attack platformer get it.

No drama, Just Reviews.

reviewText:
Man, I hope you were there when Canabalt first appeared back in 2009. It was such a mystifying experience, playing this intense, engrossing Flash game on some random dude's website. They say it was the first of the endless runner genre, and even if it weren't, it would deserve a place of honor among them.

You'll never know who your hapless lady or fellow is, or why their city is being annihilated by shadowy engines of destruction, but you won't have much time to wonder, either. Canabalt is a one-button game, and that button is jump. Your character runs to the right at an ever-increasing clip, and you need to jump them from rooftop to rooftop to billboard to girder to whatever else is in your path. Each run is randomized, with obstacles, crumbling buildings, windows, and occasional attacks from the marauding machines.

It's a simple premise, but the presentation takes it to another level. Set to pulse-pounding tracks, your journey through the chaos is all in silky-smooth, heavily-detailed gray-scale. Flocks of birds take flight as you charge past, the engines of destruction level buildings in the layered background, and stranger things still float past if you make it far enough. And if the presentation wasn't enough, there's a layer of strategy to the game as well. Letting your runner build up too much speed makes them hard to control, so sometimes you need to strategically hit an obstacle or two to slow them down.

A few of the obstacles, like the windows and walker legs, are quite difficult to overcome and can end some runs in frustration, but they hardly ruin the game. This HD version also comes with a 3D mode that stays true to the look and feel of the original, 8 challenge runs with different themes, and a two-player mode that can be played solo as a very interesting test of coordination. The original might be free, but if you have any love for infinite runners this will be a worthy addition to your library.

reviewText:
Ahh. Canabalt.

I've loved this game ever since I got it on my iPod Touch back in 2011. It was a really fun infinite runner and paved the way for many to follow (and in some cases, copy).

This game needs no introduction. You run and jump to try and stay alive.

I got the HD version on my Samsung Galaxy Note 2 in early 2013 but that didn't really do much for me. This Steam release, though, brings you everything and then some.

Enhanced graphics (seriously, who knew that what started as a humble flash game would allow you to go up to 8x anti-aliasing), responsive control(s), touchscreen and controller support, multiplayer and the selection of levels to play and music help make this definitely worth playing if you're a fan of the original and even if you're not.

But seriously. The multiplayer and touchscreen support is a godsend. I've been searching for Steam games for my Dell Venue 8 Pro tablet and Canabalt has been one of the most promising results. Now I don't have to play 2-player Flappy Bird when I pull out my tablet with friends!
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
This game is pure adrenaline. As you run across rooftops, dodging bombs and jumping through windows while listening to the music of Danny Baranowsky and Mega Ran, you're on the edge of your seat as you close the gap towards your previous record.

Canabalt is an auto-runner, but don't let that put you off, since this was the first and still the best. There are several new features to justify the price, such as more characters, multiplayer, more music, 3D and new obstacles.

I like to imagine that the whole game is some idiot overreacting to a demolition project, and running from things that were supposed to destroy abandoned buildings.

9/10

You can barely see anything, because the screen moves so quickly and there is nothing to focus your eyes on... That, I suppose, is the main component of the difficulty.

And I'm pretty sure there are situations in which you can't know the right course of action, so even a perfect player can lose due to bad luck.

There are much better games, even for this price.

reviewText:
Play Super Hexagon and Boson X instead. They are the same thing and significantly better IMO. Better twitch gameplay and far better music. A great endless runner owes about 50% of its greatness to the music score.

I bought this game for my iPhone a while ago, and didn't really feel it then either. I thought I would try again. It is fine, but there are betters out there.

My main problems:

1. The one-button mechanic is a bit too simple (hence it was a phone game first)
2. The roof running thing is not exciting enough to carry this game - maybe needs a slightly more refined mechanic? I am not sure
3. Just do not feel compelled to keep playing

I'd pass on this unless you have exhausted all (the better) other endless runners.

reviewText:
There's a flash game of this out there. This game is pretty much exactly that, But now you can play it full screen, 2 player, there are achievements, alternative modes and a 3D version of the graphics (I still prefer the pixel art style).

These are all minor upgrades, but it's a really cheap game.

Great if you just want a challenge, or to pass the time, nice and simple!

reviewText: The Endless Runner" genre of games owes it's livelihood to Canabalt. Without this humble little flash game taking the internet by storm
date: we would have never seen the creation of Temple Run and other classics (Jetpack Joyride
hoursPlayed: etc). While some people may not care for that style of gaming
voteText:
there is a simplicity within that makes the game extremely addicting and furiously challenging.

The goal is to simply survive as long as you can. The level is always randomized and will get progressively harder as you stay alive. The speed picks up and new obstacles are thrown at you. You have mere split-seconds to react or die. The simple controls give you enough dominion over your character to make every move; the only thing keeping you back is your reaction time.

That would be about it for a review
helpfulPercent: but this Steam version includes the updated port that was released on mobile devices a few years back. With that
votesHelpful: you get some "3D" graphics and a 2-player mode with challenges. The 3D is pointless as the sprite work in the original is gorgeous. There is no need to even bother with the remixed visuals.\n\nAs for the 2-player mode
votesTotal: it is a nice touch. I can't say the game is preferable with 2 people
votesFunny: but it certainly is a nice addition for the truly addicted. Challenge mode is where the real thought went. I like how each level is basically a set of stipulations that require you to still react to random levels.\n\nThe only problem is that 2-player mode makes a joke of those challenges. As far as completion goes
commentsCount: you just need to reach a set distance and you've finished the challenge. Since 2-player doubles your score (as long as both players are alive)
column16: you end up doing each challenge twice as fast.\n\nYou can up the ante and play both players by your lonesome. It does make for some intense situations where one player drifts away faster than the other. Your brain has problems reacting to two different objects and the outcome is often fatal. Still
column17: I feel like challenge mode could have been expanded for 2-player.\n\nEither way
column18: this updated port is great. It may be a bit late to the game
column19: but nothing is truly wrong with this version. I guess it wouldn't hurt to ask for some more content with challenge mode
column20: but the rest is basically as good as it has ever been.\n\nThe price isn't even bad
column21: either. $3 might seem like a lot
column22: but you will definitely get your moneys worth. If nothing else
column23: the Humble Bundle edition from a few years back came with a Steam key
column24: so you may even own this without knowing.\n\n8/10"

reviewText: Best one-button game I've ever played, hands down. Full of adrenaline and has a lot of variety to it saying you only use one button. Plus, it's stupidly addictive! Well worth the £2.
